intro: Moehringia castellana, commonly known as the mountain mouse-ear, is a low-growing perennial plant native to the mountainous regions of Europe. It belongs to the family Caryophyllaceae and is characterized by its small, hairy leaves and clusters of pinkish-white flowers. The plant typically thrives in rocky or gravelly soils and is often found in alpine or subalpine habitats. It is a member of the genus Moehringia, which includes several species with similar morphological features. Moehringia castellana is valued for its ornamental appeal and is sometimes cultivated in gardens with well-drained soil.
